metadata.case_name: Bhagat Raja v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Notification dated January 8, 1964 published in the State Gazette by the Andhra Pradesh Government inviting applications under r. 58 of the Rules framed under the Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957.
Appellant submitted two applications in Form I for mining lease for asbestos over Ac. 113-50 in Brahmanapalli village and Ac. 13-10 in Ippatta village, both in Cuddapah District.
Respondent No. 3 (M/s. Tiffins Barytes, Asbestos and Paints Ltd.) made similar applications on the same date.
Appellant's applications complied with all requirements of Form I; those of Respondent No. 3 were defective.
One other person applied for prospecting licence, rejected outright.

Government of Andhra Pradesh preferred Respondent No. 3 by order dated October 19, 1964 under s.10(3) of the Act: 'As between the other applicants Sri Bhagat Raja and M/s. Tiffins Barytes, Asbestos and Paints Ltd., the Government prefer M/s. Tiffins Barytes as they are having adequate general experience and technical knowledge, and are old lessees in the district, without any arrears of mineral dues to the Government.'

Appellant filed revision applications in Form N under s.30 of the Act read with r.54 to Union of India on December 14, 1964, highlighting precarious financial condition of Respondent No. 3 evidenced by documents.
Respondent No. 3 filed counter-statement to revision in April 1965.
Appellant filed rejoinder to counter-statement in May 1965.
Comments of Andhra Pradesh Government received by appellant in March 1966.
Appellant filed rejoinder to comments of Andhra Pradesh Government in April 1966.
Appellant requested personal hearing, not granted.

Union of India rejected revision by orders dated May 2, 1966 and June 22, 1966: 'after careful consideration of the grounds stated therein, the Central Government have come to the conclusion that there is no valid ground for interfering with the decision of the Government of Andhra Pradesh... Your application for revision is, therefore, rejected.'

legal_issues.text: Whether in dismissing a revision and confirming the order of the State of Andhra Pradesh, the Union of India was bound to make a speaking order.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent No. 3 had no experience in asbestos mining, financial position unsatisfactory, application not in proper form.
Union of India exercising quasi-judicial powers under s.30 of the Act read with rr.54 and 55 bound to give reasons; principles of natural justice violated; personal hearing should have been given.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.30 Mines and Minerals Act; rr.54,55 Mineral Concession Rules; natural justice

respondent_arguments.text: No obligation to give reasons for decision in revision under r.55 as it does not envisage fresh pleadings but only comments; r.26 requires reasons only from State Government.

court_reasoning.text: Central Government under r.55 exercises quasi-judicial functions as a tribunal; must consider not only material before State but comments and counter-comments; opportunity to show State erred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quasi-judicial authority must give speaking order, especially appealable under Art.136.

court_reasoning.text: Non-speaking orders disadvantage appellate court; State reasons scrappy, Central must clarify or adopt; here order shows only no ground for interference, not own reasoning.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Speaking order ensures fairness, minimizes arbitrariness.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes cases where reasons obvious or lower gave full reasons; here State reasons inadequate (old lessee etc.), Central must indicate mind.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No merit in no-reasons for affirmance; r.26 lightens burden as State gives reasons.

holdings.text: Central Government exercising revisional powers under r.55 is a quasi-judicial tribunal bound to give reasons (speaking order) for its decision.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivji Nathubhai v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Central Govt under r.54 Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 acts judicially as tribunal.

precedents_cited.case_name: M.P. Industries v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Central Govt quasi-judicial under r.55; must give reasons; scheme posits judicial procedure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Judicial/quasi-judicial tribunal must give reasons for Art.136 appeal effectiveness.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sardar Govindrao v. State of M.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Govt must act quasi-judicially, give reasons and hearing.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nandram Hunatram v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Reasons obvious in facts, not required to repeat; dissimilar here.
Tribunal agreeing with lower without new grounds need not repeat if lower reasoned; inapplicable as State reasons inadequate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal ex p. Shaw
precedents_cited.relevance: Speaking orders beneficial for review by certiorari.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates grant/refusal of mining leases; s.10(3) State may grant/refuse; s.11(3) criteria for preference; s.30 Central revision.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Application in Form I; State must give reasons for refusal (r.26); revision procedure with comments/counter-comments (r.55); quasi-judicial.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; orders of Central Government dated June 22, 1966 set aside; Central Government directed to decide revision applications afresh in light of observations.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to Central Government for fresh decision with speaking order.

key_quotes.text: "The condition of giving reasons is only attached to an order made by the Government when it functions judicially as a tribunal... A reasoned order is a desirable condition of judicial disposal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes duty of quasi-judicial tribunals to give speaking orders.

key_quotes.text: "If tribunals can make orders without giving reasons, the said power in the hands of unscrupulous or dishonest officers may turn out to be a potent weapon for abuse of power."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights rationale for speaking orders to prevent arbitrariness.

key_quotes.text: "What is essential is that reasons shall be given by an appellate or revisional tribunal expressly or by reference to those given by the original tribunal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies requirement even in affirmance cases.
